author: Rachel Becker
title: Meet some #actuallivingscientists on Twitter
text:
If I were to ask you to name a living scientist, who would be your choice? A hashtag that went viral on Twitter today is aimed at expanding your range of options: #actuallivingscientist . 
The thing is, most people can’t name a living scientist — at least, according to a 2013 survey of 1,000 American adults : 70 percent of them failed to do so. That suggests the public — people who pay taxes to support scientific research — likely don’t know much about who they’re funding, what they’re funding, or what the results of their funded experiments are. That’s a problem, and one that scientists feel more urgently lately. The former Secretary of the Interior told scientists that if they didn’t make themselves heard and get to the table, they’d be on the menu . 
And it’s one that wildlife ecologist David Steen was trying to remedy when he tweeted on Thursday afternoon: “Most Americans can't name a living scientist (it's true, look it up!); no wonder they don't fully appreciate what we do. So...Hi, I'm Dave.”
“Someone was giving me a hard time about how my work wasn’t worth doing, it’s not too unusual,” Steen told The Verge . “I’m there for science communication, so I try to understand it from their perspective.” So, he introduced himself. The hashtag itself was the work of Mary Roblyer (@darthmom7): 
@AlongsideWild Hi Dave! Maybe this is a good opportunity for other scientists 2 introduce themselves with a pic and #actuallivingscientist .
— Mary Roblyer (@darthmom7) February 2, 2017 Over past day, scientists have been using the hashtag when they post pictures of themselves at work. 
Hi, I'm DNLee I study behavior & natural history of small mammals across urban gradients. #actuallivingscientist #womeninscience pic.twitter.com/UCPQJbqa6x 
— DNLee (@DNLee5) February 3, 2017 Hi, I'm Janet & I study how endangered hawks live in an environment with lots of human development. I like coffee! #actuallivingscientist pic.twitter.com/6vQbAwFls3 
— Janet Ng (@janetngbio) February 3, 2017 Hi, I'm Rachael! I study how honey #bees cope with the seasonal variation of their diet (flowers!). #ActualLivingScientist #WomenInSTEM pic.twitter.com/3rjzJLLrt1 
— Rachael Bonoan (@RachaelEBee) February 4, 2017 I'm Mercedes. As an #actuallivingscientist , I study the evolution of reproductive systems. And I wear what I want to do it #DressLikeAWoman pic.twitter.com/fmTwip8VXP 
— Mercedes Burns (@DrCedes) February 3, 2017 Hi, I'm Catherine! I'm an #actuallivingscientist who studies how black widow spiders communicate using chemicals on their silk! pic.twitter.com/WoDZcvj7Kw 
— Catherine Scott (@Cataranea) February 3, 2017 Mbola tsara! I'm Asia. I use cameras to spy on wildlife. Love writing, cheese, & scifi horror. Pvt. Vasquez = goals. #actuallivingscientist pic.twitter.com/4TujdyE8v4 
— Asia Murphy (@am_anatiala) February 3, 2017 Hi! I'm Jenna! I study turtle nesting behavior and maternal effects! I'm an #actuallivingscientist pic.twitter.com/jmRV4kWr73 
— Jenna Pruett (@TurtlesRCool2) February 3, 2017 I am an #actuallivingscientist . I pick up cheetah poop. Sometimes I drop it on myself. #DressLikeAWoman #distractinglysexy pic.twitter.com/13UOHDIDZg 
— Anne Hilborn (@AnneWHilborn) February 4, 2017 Hi, I'm Megan! I study river/stream fish & inverts & teach kids that natural resources are fun & impt #ActualLivingScientist #womeninscience pic.twitter.com/7ErQM34otR 
— Megan Gunn (@_TFFP) February 3, 2017 Some of them were posted with today’s other viral hashtag, #dresslikeawoman :
Hi I'm Christina! I'm an #actuallivingscientist studying how Arctic kelp respond to enivronmntl stressors. While working, I #DressLikeAWoman pic.twitter.com/gowZWUh3dX 
— Christina Bonsell (@c_bonsell) February 4, 2017 My name is Clara & I work on the @ATLASexperiment at @CERN . I'm an #actuallivingscientist . I #DressLikeAWomen at work - hardhat & dosimeter. pic.twitter.com/xpu3CcCkGd 
— Clara Nellist (@claranellist) February 3, 2017
